Gov. George E. Pataki of New York asserts that the death penalty bill "will protect the rights of prosecutors and the district attorneys to vigorously prosecute capital cases" (front page, Feb. 15).

As agents of the government, prosecutors do not have rights. Individuals possess rights against others, especially the government. Nowhere in the New York Constitution does it provide for "rights" belonging to the government; like its Federal counterpart, our Constitution protects the rights of citizens from government incursion, not the other way around.

The Governor's assertion poses more than semantic problems related to criminal prosecutions. If the governing theory is that the government possesses rights, individual rights of all stripe are threatened. Obviously, the government's "rights," presumptively exercised on behalf of all the people, will always outweigh the individual's rights, especially since they will be weighed on the government's scale in the government's courtroom.

Let us hope that when the death penalty bill is drafted, greater care is given to its language than Governor Pataki gave to his comments. JONATHAN P. WILLMOTT New York, Feb. 17, 1995 The writer is a Legal Aid lawyer.
